front.title: HTTP Server-ID header for determining specific anycast instance

abstract.t: This document proposes a new HTTP header field, similar to NSID for DNS queries, to add an optional identifier to the HTTP server generating the response to a request. Such a header could be used to identifier which location or server instance was reached by the user, which can be useful in anycast deployments and CDNs.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: We propose to add an OPTIONAL HTTP header, X-Server-ID. The value of such a filed is determined by the server operator; this document does not specify syntactical or semantic constraints.
The specific use-case would be to specify the identity of the server and maybe it's geographic location.

While it's not normally important to know where HTTP data is being delivered from; it can be a useful debugging tool to have that information kept in the HTTPheader. Normally, lower level protocols can be used (traceroute, ping, etc.) to determine the source end point location. With this header, the data would be there by default wihin every transaction.

Front-end load-balancers can also mask the specific server delivering data. This is sometimes the desired operational mode. In some cases, for debugging reasons, it's useful to know the actual source server.
The source IP address within an HTTP transaction normally can be mapped to a geographic location when Unicast addressesing is used. Anycast services change that dynamic.
As more and more web services are delivered from Anycast servers; it becomes harder to know which physical location information is being delivered from.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: The Header blah blah
section.t:
We propose to add an OPTIONAL HTTP header, X-Server-ID. The value of such a filed is determined by the server operator; this document SHALL NOT specify syntactical or semantic constraints. However, operators SHOULD use values that can help clients to interpret the value itself, such as geolocation codes (UNLOC, IATA codes, POP identifiers, etc.) in combination with some kind of server instances identifiers.
The length of the value for this header cannot be more than 4 kilobytes (?)
*To be checked: can multiple instances of the same header appear? If yes, say so. If not, then make the value a pussible list, with ";" as separator.

section.title: Examples
section.t: The X-Server-ID header contents can be as simple as the IATA code for the airport closest to the servers location. IATA codes are commonly used within the Internet for names of sites and links.

figure.postamble: An X-Server-ID header showing the local airport code.

section.t: More complex examples could include specific server information along with location.

figure.postamble: An X-Server-ID header showing company specific informaiton along with locations.

section.t: The X-Server-ID header data SHOULD try not to duplicate the work of existing headers. For example; not replicating the X-Powered-By or Server header informaiton.

section.title: Recursion
section.t: There needs to be a way to address recursion when HTTP headers and content pass thru proxies or caches. As HTTP header names MUST be unique and only occure once, any additional server wanting to add content to the X-Server-ID header MUST do so in an additive manner.

figure.postamble: An X-Server-ID header before a proxy or cache.
An X-Server-ID header after a proxy or cache.

section.t: As this document SHALL NOT specify syntactical or semantic constraints of the headers value, the choice of comma is up to the implementer.

section.title: The Via Header
section.t: The Via Header was introduced to detect loops when proxies or caches are used within the HTTP path. The proposed X-Server-ID header works independently from that header and doesn't change it's usefullness or functionality.

section.title: Acknowledgements
section.t: This work was propted by the work of the RIPE Atlas project and it's need to indentify HTTP servers when they are Anycast. In addition, this work is based on the existing CF- HTTP header used within CloudFlare's Anycast CDN deployment.
This document is in-part a generalization and specification of already existing company-specific solutions.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This memo includes no request to IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t:
This header, by its very nature, exposes the existence of web servers or co-location sites or both. Server operators who are concerned abot this exposure should not opt in to this feature.
NOTE: technically speaking, the "Server" header could be abused. As of now, this should say "Apache 2.2.x" or such, but it could say "Apache 2.2.x @ LAX-2" as well. I'm arguing that this would be an overload, though it's a simple one to tweak...
